description:
Potato leafroll virus (PLRV) is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus that belongs to the genus Polerovirus within the family Luteoviridae. It is an economically important pathogen that infects potato (Solanum tuberosum) plants, causing a disease known as potato leafroll.

The PLRV genome is approximately 5.9 kilobases in length and encodes several essential proteins, including the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, movement proteins, and the coat protein. The virus is transmitted by several species of aphids, primarily the green peach aphid (Myzus persicae), in a persistent, circulative manner.

Infection by PLRV leads to a characteristic set of symptoms in potato plants, including leaf rolling, stunting, and yellowing of the leaves. The virus primarily affects the phloem tissues of the plant, interfering with the transport of nutrients and resulting in reduced growth and yield. PLRV can be spread through the use of infected seed potatoes, making it a significant concern for potato production worldwide.

Control strategies for PLRV typically involve the use of virus-free seed potatoes, the application of insecticides to manage aphid populations, and the deployment of resistant or tolerant potato cultivars. Continued research on the molecular mechanisms of PLRV infection and the development of novel control methods are important areas of focus for the management of this economically significant plant virus.
